description: From Middle English grape, from Old French grape, grappe, crape (“cluster of fruit or flowers, bunch of grapes”), from graper, craper (“to pick grapes”, literally “to hook”), of Germanic origin, from Frankish *krappō (“hook”), from Proto-Indo-European *greb- (“hook”), *gremb- (“crooked, uneven”), from *ger- (“to turn, bend, twist”). Cognate with Middle Dutch krappe (“hook”), Old High German krapfo (“hook”) (whence German Krapfen (“Berliner doughnut”). Doublet of grappa. More at cramp.

adjectives.description: grape (comparative more grape, superlative most grape)

entries.meaning: Containing grapes or having a grape flavor.
Of a dark purplish red colour.
(countable) A small, round, smooth-skinned edible fruit, usually purple, red, or green, that grows in bunches on vines of genus Vitis.
examples: Grapes give us whole-fruit snacks, grape juice, raisins, wine, and more.

entries.meaning: (countable, uncountable) A woody vine of genus Vitis that bears clusters of grapes; a grapevine.
examples: wild grape covering the back slope

entries.meaning: (countable) Any of various fruits or plants with varying resemblances to those of genus Vitis but belonging to other genera; their edibility varies.
(countable, uncountable) A dark purplish-red colour, the colour of many grapes.
examples: For those seeking purply tones, the paint colors available include mauve, magenta, and grape.

entries.meaning: A mangy tumour on a horse's leg.
(US, naval slang) A purple-shirted technician responsible for refueling aircraft.
examples: I was horrified to see three grapes standing by the aircraft with the hose still connected.

entries.meaning: (US, slang, colloquial, African-American Vernacular) A person's head.

verbs.description: grape (third-person singular simple present grapes, present participle graping, simple past and past participle graped)

entries.meaning: (of livestock) To develop tubercules as a result of tuberculosis.
To develop a texture with small grape-like clusters of a contaminant or foreign substance.
(dialect, Hong Kong) To envy (derived from "sour grapes" idiom).
